text:
2. With perusal of these precepts,
the best of men will understand
the famous teachings on true duty,
on good and bad, on what to do or not.

3. These I now fully display,
wishing to benefit all the people;
merely by understanding them,
one may obtain omniscience.

4. Guard wealth for times adverse, it’s said,
but for the rich where is adversity?
But, when wealth does begin to shift,
even that amassed will destroyed be.

5. In lands where one gets no respect,
no livelihood, and has no kin,
nor to learning any access,
abjure all staying therein.

6. Learned priests, kind moneylenders,
a ruler, rivers and some physician:
a place where these five absent are,
there do not stay for one day even.

7. Means of living, shame and fear,
courtesy and generosity:
where these five do not exist,
any abode there should not be.

8. Know servants by directing them,
and kinsfolk, when times are troubled,
the friend, in some calamity,
and the wife in loss of prosperity.

9. In times of sickness or bad luck,
in famines and enemy attacks,
at the ruler’s door or in the cemetery,
the friend is one who stands by you.

10. One who discards the permanent,
and pursues just the transient—
the first values are by him destroyed,
the second perish in any case.

11. Nectar seek, even from poison,
gold even from excrement,
knowledge even from one base,
and the girl that is a gem,
even from a family low.

12. Double is women’s appetite,
their wisdom four times more than men,
their courage and daring six times more,
their lust eightfold, it is believed.

2
1. One with a son under control,
a wife who does his wishes follow,
one with his status content,
for him, heaven is here itself.

2. A true son is to the father loyal,
and a father true, who nourishes him,
a true friend is one who can be trusted,
and a true wife, who gives tranquillity.

3. He speaks before you sweetly,
but spoils the work behind your back:
such a friend should be discarded—
like a poisoned pot with milk on top.

4. Do not trust one not a friend,
and not too much even a friend,
for, when annoyed with you, the latter
can your secrets public make.

5. Some work considered in the mind,
when speaking do not public make,
just think about it privately,
till it is indeed accomplished.

6. There are no gems in every mountain,
no pearl within each elephant,
no sandalwood in all the forests,
nor good people everywhere.

7. The wise always equip their children
with virtues of every kind,
as righteous and versed in decorum,
they earn respect in the family.

8. That mother is an enemy, that father a foe,
by whom their child is not educated;
among others, it will then be,
like a stork among the swans.

9. Indulgence has many defects,
and discipline many merits;
as such the son, and the pupil too,
do not spoil but strictly treat.

10. Separation from one’s beloved,
insults from one’s family,
persisting debts, a bad king serving,
poverty and bad company:
these can, without a fire even,
burn a person bodily.

11. Priestly power lies in learning,
that of kings is the army,
the merchants’ power is in money,
and in service of the menials.

12. Wicked, and badly behaved,
he lives ill, casts evil looks—
one who makes of such a person
a friend will soon get destroyed.

3
1. Which family is free of faults,
which person has not suffered disease,
who has not faced adversity,
whose happiness is permanent?

2. Conduct points to the family,
speech indicates the land,
respect reflects affection,
and the body what one eats.

3. Between a snake and a wicked person,
the serpent is to be preferred;
it may bite, but only sometimes,
the wicked do so at every step.

4. The reason why rulers employ
people from noble families
is that they do not forsake the king
at the beginning, midway or his end.

5. Those born in high-class families,
and bright with youth and beauty,
devoid of learning, have no merit,
like flowers with no fragrance.

6. For the family, forsake one person,
for the village, forsake the family,
forsake the village for the country,
but for yourself, forsake the world.

7. For beauty great was Sita seized,
Ravana slain for too much pride,
for giving too much was Bali bound—
as such, always, excess avoid.

8. What is too hard for an able person,
what place too far for one in trade,
what land too foreign for the learned,
and an alien for one sweet of speech?

9. Even by a single tree,
with flowers full of fragrance,
the forest whole becomes sweet-scented,
like, with a good child, the family.

10. With a single dried-up tree,
burning with a fire fierce,
the whole forest is set ablaze,
like with a bad child, the family.

11. Spoil him for the first five years,
for the next ten, discipline him,
but once the son becomes sixteen,
treat him like a friend.

12. From fearful famines and epidemics,
from attacks by the enemy,
and from contacts with the wicked,
to stay alive one has to flee.

4
1. One’s length of life, one’s work and wealth,
one’s learning, also one’s demise:
these five have been already fixed
while in the mother’s womb one lies.

2. The fish, the turtle and the bird
care for their young, respectively,
through sight and care and physical touch;
this is also what does happen
when keeping company with good people.

3. Till this body is in good health,
and death is still far away,
do your work, benefits obtain;
what can be done once life is gone?

4. Learning is like a holy cow,
it gives benefits in times of need,
in foreign lands it’s like a mother,
and also a source of hidden wealth.

5. Better a child that dies at birth
than one long living, but a fool;
one gives pain for just a while,
the other as long as it is alive.

6. The king’s command is given but once,
just once an expert’s view put forth,
girls are given but once in marriage:
these three take place only once.

7. That is a wife: one pure and skilled,
and devoted to her spouse,
one who is by her husband loved,
and who speaks the truth.

8. Without a child, one’s house is empty,
with no kinsfolk are quarters all;
empty is the head of a fool,
and, of all things, poverty.

9. Books are poison with no study,
just as food in constipation,
courts are poison for the poor,
as young women for aged men.

10. The progenitor and the natal priest,
one who provides education,
the giver of food, one’s fear reliever:
these five have a father’s citation.

11. The king’s consort, the guru’s spouse,
and the wife of a friend,
one’s wife’s mother and one’s own:
these five do as mothers stand.

5
1. As gold is tested in four ways—
by friction, scratches, heat and sound—
so men too need to be examined:
for their merit and character,
for work and for renunciation.

2. Do not be afraid of terror
as long as it has not occurred;
and seeing it has come to be,
then resist it fearlessly.

3. They may come from a single womb,
and under the same star be born,
but their nature is not the same,
as with a berry and a thorn.

5. Fools hate learned people,
the poor those with prosperity,
the whores hate pious women,
the widows those that well-married be.

6. Virtue is by wealth protected,
learning by discipline,
by mercy is a king kept safe,
and the house by good women.

7. Gifting nullifies penury,
character some misfortune,
wisdom, ignorance removes,
and due meditation, fear.

8. Like sexual lust there is no sickness,
like delusion, no enemy,
like anger there is no conflagration,
and nothing like knowledge to happy be.

9. One is born and dies alone,
enjoys alone the good and bad,
one also goes to hell alone,
or achieves final salvation.

10. In foreign lands, one’s friend is learning,
at home it is the wife,
in sickness, the friend is medicine,
in death it is the virtuous life.

11. Rain is meaningless on the seas,
as food is for one full,
or cash donation to one rich,
and a lamp lit in the day.

12. The rogue among men is the barber,
midst birds, it is the crow,
amid four-footed beasts, it is the jackal,
and among women it is
she who strings the garlands.

6
1. Through listening to what scriptures say,
one does dharma understand
and wicked thinking discard
to obtain the wisdom true,
thus attaining salvation.

2. Of birds, the lowest type is a crow,
of animals, it is the dog,
of sages, one who is always angry,
but the worst are they who others revile.

3. A brass vessel is cleansed with ash,
a copper one with citric juice,
women are cleansed by menstruation,
and rivers by their flowing fast.

4. A king who tours is well-respected,
as also one of the priestly class,
so too are holy men and yogis,
but a vagrant woman gets destroyed.

5. Time devours all creatures,
it destroys the populace,
it passes as one sleeps or wakens,
its movement is unstoppable.

6. One born blind just cannot see,
nor one blinded by desire,
or maddened with alcohol—
one selfish can’t see his own faults.

7. One’s self takes action on its own,
and also its fruit receives,
alone it wanders in the world,
and by itself attains liberation.

8. The king bears sins done by the state,
his own sins by the priests are borne,
and the wife’s sins by her husband,
of disciples by their guru.

9. The father in debt is one’s enemy,
and the mother who is adulterous,
a beautiful wife is also a foe,
as is a son without education.

10. One greedy can be lured with wealth,
one arrogant with folded hands,
a fool with fictitious behaviour,
but the wise only with truth.

11. Better not live in a state at all
than in one that is badly run,
better to have no friend at all
than a bad and treacherous one,
better not have any disciple
than those who may be wicked,
and better be without a wife
than have one of bad character.

12. Where is people’s happiness,
in the kingdom of a wicked ruler?
And where satisfaction, with a friend
who becomes unfriendly?
In teaching bad disciples too,
where can one get fame?
And where is love, within that house
where the wife is really bad?

7
1. Wise folk do not publicize
their loss of wealth, mind’s agony,
being tricked, getting insulted,
or bad goings-on at home.

2. In exchanging grain for cash,
in acquisition of learning,
in getting food and right behaviour,
do not hesitate, and happy be.

3. The happiness of one at peace
with the nectar of contentment,
comes not to those, greedy for wealth,
who run here and there.

4. With three one should remain content:
the spouse, the food and property;
with three this should be never done:
study, austerity, charity.

5. Too upright, straight, one should not be,
go to the forest and there see:
straight trees cut down repeatedly,
while standing stays the crooked tree.

6. For the money one has earned,
good spending is the best protection,
as for an overflowing tank of water,
its draining is the best solution.

7. One with money also has
friends as well as kin,
one so endowed is well regarded,
and indeed has a life in this world.

8. Those who live here, as in heaven,
display these four signs:
gentle talk, a charitable nature,
god’s worship, priestly satisfaction.

9. Bitter speech, excess of anger,
discord with kin, much poverty,
contacts and service with the base:
these are four signs of in hell to be.

10. Going to the cave, a lion’s palace,
one may find an elephant’s temple pearl,
but he gets in a jackal’s hovel
just a calf’s skin or a donkey’s tail.

11. To live without any learning is
like a tail-less dog,
to hide its private parts unable,
or to ward off mosquitoes.

12. With discrimination, one discerns,
oil in sesame, scent in flowers
in wood, fire, in milk, ghee,
and one’s self within the body.

8
1. Base people wish mainly for wealth,
the middling, both wealth and respect,
just respect is sought by the best,
that alone is wealth for the great.

2. Purification rituals, like
the bath, the gifting and the others,
need not be done before partaking
of sugar cane, water, milk and medicine,
fruit, health-giving roots, and betel leaf.

3. A lamp consumes the darkness,
and gives birth to soot;
thus too, the food that one eats
leads to similar progeny.

4. Wise one, give your money to
only those possessing merit—
look at the water by the sea given,
which is always sweetened in the cloud
that then enlivens all creation,
and, earning merits thousandfold,
then goes back to the ocean.

5. Discerning scholars have commented
that the lowest of the low
among the base, who are in thousands,
is the yavana, or barbarian,
nothing can be more vile.

6. With the body rubbed in oil,
or touched by smoke from a funeral pyre,
after sex, or getting shaved,
till a bath, one remains impure.

7. In constipation, water is
a medicine, and a tonic later,
with a meal, it is like nectar,
but a poison at its end.

8. In one’s old age, the wife’s demise,
wealth passing into kinsfolk’s hands,
and food dependent on some other:
all three cause deep distress to men.

9. No penance compares to search for peace,
no happiness to being content,
the worst illness is strong desires,
no virtue as great as mercy.

10. Anger is like the king of hell,
and like hell’s river is desire,
but learning is the cow divine,
and contentment, heaven’s garden.

11. Dissatisfaction destroys priests,
and satisfaction kings,
modesty destroys the whore,
and indecency, family women.

12. Those who eat meat and drink wine,
and the fools who stay illiterate,
they all are beasts in human garb,
and the earth suffers their weight.

9
1. My dear, if you seek salvation,
leave sensual pleasure like a poison,
and drink the nectar of forgiveness,
of sincerity, mercy, purity.

2. The people base, given to gossip
about each other’s secrets,
are all heading for destruction,
like the snake within an anthill.

3. At the beginning, there was no one
to give a mind to the Creator:
to gold he did not give a scent,
to stalks of sugar cane no fruit,
to the sandalwood tree no flowers.
Scholars were not well-off made,
nor kings granted longevity.

4. Of all remedies nectar is the best,
of pleasures, that of eating,
eyes are the best of all the organs,
and of limbs it is the head.

5. No courier did bring news from there,
no one was met who talked about it;
but one who knows, and public makes
the eclipse of the sun and moon
that will take place in the sky,
how can he not learned be?

6. A student, servant or a traveller,
one suffering hunger, or in fear,
a treasurer or a guard: these seven,
if asleep, one should awaken.

7. These seven, do not awaken:
a snake, a sleeping king, a tiger,
a wild boar, or a little child,
a fool, or someone else’s dog.

8. One whose wrath creates no fear,
or any wealth his satisfaction,
one who cannot help or hinder,
what is the meaning of his anger?

9. Even a snake, though venomless,
should spread out a hood so large,
that though indeed it has no poison,
its appearance can cause fear.

10. Talk of gambling in the morning,
of a woman in the afternoon,
and, at night, of thievery:
with such stories from the scriptures
do the wise spend time.

11. A garland strung with one’s own hands,
sandal paste, by oneself made,
and a self-written verse of prayer:
use of these, while worshipping,
bestows more than Indra’s glory.

12. Penury looks fine with fortitude,
bad garments with their being clean,
being ugly with character
,
and ill-cooked food when eaten warm.

2. What do not the poets look at,
what can women not commit,
what will not the drunkards rant,
and what do not the crows devour?

4. Those who have no learning,
austerity or charity,
nor any character,
any merit or virtue,
they are just animals
in a human form,
and also a burden
put upon the earth.

5. No instruction has any result
on those who are empty inside—
the bamboo grows on Malaya hills too,
but it cannot turn into sandalwood.

6. There is no method on this earth
to turn bad things into good:
the anus, washed a hundred times,
cannot become the mouth.

7. Better in a forest live
with elephants and lions,
on a tree, for one’s abode,
with fruit and leaves as food,
of the twigs making a bed,
and of the barks a garment,
than to live without any money
midst family and kin.

8. Birds of many colours,
resting on the same tree,
in the morning fly away
in different directions:
in this is there any cause
for lamentation and regret?

9. Real strength lies in intelligence.
Where is it in fools?
A forest lion, mad with pride,
can be brought down by a rabbit.

10. Well-versed in our speech divine,
I long for other languages too:
like gods in heaven, quaffing nectar,
seek some wine from the lips of nymphs.

11. Flour is ten times better than grain,
milk ten times more than flour,
meat is tenfold better than milk,
and ghee similarly more than meat.

12. With bad herbs do illnesses spread,
the body grows with milk,
with ghee does the semen increase,
and bodily flesh by eating meat.

11
1. The spirit of doing charity,
or for speaking sweetly,
of courage and fortitude,
and knowing propriety:
all four are natural qualities
that can’t by practise be acquired.

3. Though in many ways educated,
the wicked cannot good become:
just as watering its roots with milk and ghee
will not sweeten the fruit of the lemon tree.

4. One who eats in silence
for one entire year
will in heaven be respected
for millions of ages.

5. Anger, greed and sexual lust,
taste, amusement, ornamentation,
an excess of both sleep and service:
these seven the student should abjure.

6. Satisfied with a single meal,
always bent on six activities,
with sex only after his wife’s period:
one such is twice born in caste.

7. Fully involved in worldly duties,
protector of the animals,
given to trade and agriculture,
one so inclined is a merchant called.

8. He sells lac and other dyes,
some blue, and others flower-coloured;
oil and ghee, liquor and meat,
one so given, is a low caste, shudra.

9. One who spoils the work of others,
his own pursues with arrogance,
is a cheat, opponent, soft and cruel,
that person is of the lowest caste.

10. Wells and temples, lakes and mansions,
he destroys without hesitation,
one who is inspired thus
is a mlechha or barbarian.

11. He lives on the treasures of gods and temples,
and seduces the wives of others.
Among all creatures, such a one
is known as chandala, or the lowest.

12. Wealth, which is to be enjoyed,
the good give away, do not amass:
the fame of Karna, Bali,
Vikrama
is still there, even today.
But when their honey, long collected,
and not donated or enjoyed,
is now destroyed, the bees do mourn,
as they weep, rubbing their stings together.

12
1. Blessed is that householder’s life
whose house is happy, children skilled,
wealth is sufficient, girls speak sweetly,
the wife is loved, servants are loyal,
guests welcomed with tasty dishes,
best relations kept with good folk,
and Shiva worshipped every day.

2. Courtesy to one’s own people,
pity for others, with the wicked, cunning,
for the virtuous, love, for the bad, contempt,
with enemies valour, elders tolerance,
with the learned, all sincerity,
and with women, sauciness:
by men adept in all these arts,
the world’s well-being is ensured.

3. Is it a fault of the season, spring,
that kareera trees are leafless?
Is it a blemish on the sun
if owls cannot in daytime see?
Is it the sin of clouds if raindrops
don’t fall in the mouths of chataka birds?
Well, that which is decreed by fate,
by whom can it be set aside?

4. Villains can attain some goodness
in good people’s company,
but in being with them, the good
do not fall into villainy;
the earth does absorb the scent
of flowers on it planted,
but those blooms are not affected
by the odour of that ground.

5. ‘Sir, what is great inside this city?’
‘It is that palm tree grove;
the best donor is that washerman
who each night brings back the clothes.’
‘And who is clever?’ ‘All men are
in grabbing wealth and others’ wives.’
‘Then, how can you, O Friend, live here?’
‘Like an insect in this poison bred.’

6. Truth is my mother, knowledge father,
brother virtue, sister mercy,
my wife is peace, forgiveness my son:
these six are my blood relations.

7. Bodies are not permanent,
nor affluence eternal,
death is always at one’s bedside:
so, one must gather goodness.

9. Attention to virtue, in speech sweetness,
an eagerness for charity,
with friends, honesty, elders courtesy,
and seriousness in one’s mind,
pure behaviour, love for merits,
of scriptures, knowledge, in looks, beauty,
and to Shiva, all devotion:
all these are seen in good folk only.

11. One who speaks without consideration,
likes quarrelling without support,
and for all things is too eager,
such a person gets soon destroyed.

12. Falling drops of water do
gradually fill up a pitcher:
such is the way of knowledge too,
also of virtue and of wealth.

13
1. It is worth living for just a moment,
engaged in virtuous deeds;
but not for an age, and painfully,
in work that does conflict with goodness.

2. Do not grieve for what is gone,
nor think about the future,
wise folk act according to
needs of a present nature.

3. Being pleased is in the nature
of gods, good people, and a father,
kinsfolk are pleased by food and drink,
and scholars by respectful words.

4. Love for anything causes fear,
for it is attached to pain,
love, indeed, is the root of sorrow,
give it up and live in peace.

5. One for an emergency prepared,
and one who fights when it does come—
both can happily live; however,
not one who thinks it is pre-destined.

6. Virtuous when the king is too,
and also sinful when he is such,
they are fated to follow him:
as is the ruler, so are people.

7. Dharma, Artha, Kama, Moksha
are the four ends of human effort;
one who pursues not even a single goal,
meaningless is his existence,
just like the udder on a he-goat.

8. Burning in the fierce flame
of another person’s fame,
and unable to have the same,
the base just vilify and blame.

9. Who can ever obtain them,
all pleasures that the mind deserves?
Know they are in the hands of fate,
and in contentment take refuge.

10. As among a thousand cows,
the calf seeks just its mother,
so do deeds done in the past
always follow the doer.

11. The lessons from a guru come
to a caring student,
as water from the ground appears
to one who digs with a spade.

14
1. There are just three gems on the earth:
water, food and well-said verses;
it is fools who call those precious
that are but pieces of stone.

2. Wife and wealth, estate and friends,
they can all be had again;
but not birth in human form,
that one is not sure to regain.

3. Large groups of people, joined together,
can defeat the enemy—
rain on a hut is kept away
by a roof of twigs that you may see.

4. The thoughts that come at a holy sermon,
in an illness or at a cemetery,
if they then did stay all the time,
from worldly bonds one would be free.

5. With charity, penance or valour,
with science or kind policy,
one should never be surprised,
for, many gems in this earth be.

6. Separated, but still not distant,
is one who lives in the other’s mind,
one who is not in the other’s heart
may nearby be, but is far away.

8. If you wish, with a single deed,
to keep the world with you,
then keep the cow, that is your tongue,
away from grazing in the fields
of reviling other people.

9. Words in keeping with the subject,
love in line with influence,
anger in accord with power:
those knowing these are indeed wise.

10. A single subject can become
threefold depending on the viewer:
the yogi sees it as a corpse,
the lustful man, a sexy girl,
and the dog a piece of flesh.

11. Good works, wealth and foodgrains,
medicines and the guru’s words,
should all be gathered well and used,
if one is to live properly.

12. Give up bad people’s company,
that of the good folk cultivate,
day and night, do righteous things,
and also, always remember,
that nothing is permanent.

15
1. What need of hair matted with ashes,
of wisdom, and even salvation,
for one whose heart has always melted
with mercy for all creation.

2. There can be only two reactions
to wicked people and to thorns,
with a shoe to break their barbs,
or to avoid them from afar.

3. Dirty clothes and unclean teeth,
eating too much, speaking harshly,
at sunrise sleeping, also at sunset,
lead to losing all one’s glory,
even for Vishnu, discus-bearer.

4. Friends leave one who has no money,
also servants, kinsfolk, even one’s wife,
but all come back when he has wealth—
that is man’s real friend on this earth.

5. Wealth, obtained illegally,
lasts only for ten years;
once the eleventh comes,
from the root it is destroyed.

6. The unfit is fit for the great,
the fit is sinful for the base,
poison is god Shiva’s jewel,
and nectar did cause Rahu’s death.

7. A gem may roll before one’s feet,
a piece of glass adorn his head,
but, at the time of sale and purchase,
the gem is a gem and glass just glass.

8. All four Vedas do they know,
and many holy scriptures,
but not their own individual self—
just as the ladle knows not a curry’s taste.

9. The moon is filled with nectar,
the best of all medicaments,
its body too is glorious,
but when it comes into solar orbit,
all its glory is there lost—
who does not have some diminution
on entering another’s realm?

10. There are many entanglements
other than the ties of love;
the bee can penetrate some wood,
but stays quiet within the lotus.

12.
A mountain you lifted from earth,
on your smallest finger, in a game;
for that, both in heaven and here,
as the cow protector you are acclaimed.
‘O Keshava,’ the mother says,
‘I bore you on my breast.
But no one takes account of that.
What use is speaking of it—
fame comes only with holiness.’

16
1. To cut the worldly bonds, we did not
suitably meditate on god,
nor did we good deeds record
for opening the gates of heaven,
nor, even in a dream, embrace
a woman’s lovely breasts—
we were no more than an axe
that cut through our mother’s youth.

2. Who is not glad, in wealth obtaining,
in love, of problems disappearing,
whose heart is not by a woman pierced,
and who indeed is dear to kings?
Which beggar, prestige acquires,
which traveller can his goal attain
when caught in sweet words of the wicked,
and who is not in the grasp of time?

3. An antelope plated with gold
was never made by anyone,
never seen or heard about;
even so did Rama seek it—
indeed, the mind becomes perverse
at the time of some calamity.

4. Can merits greater become
by being on the highest seat?
Sitting atop a mansion tower,
can a crow become an eagle?

5. Even with the best of merits,
one suffers without support:
thus, a priceless precious stone
needs to be set in gold.

7. What may be done with wealth
that is only like a bride—
not a prostitute that can
be enjoyed by the wayside?

8. A twig is slight, cotton wool slighter,
and even more so, a beggar:
by the wind why is he not blown away
before he comes to beg from me?

9. All people can be satisfied
with a gift of some sweet words;
in giving them why act so poor?
Rather, speak them more.

10. There are two fruits like nectar
on this worldly poison tree,
they are: pleasure in poetry,
and good people’s company.

11. When charity, penance and study
have been practised in many births,
such actions lead to further lives
when they can be continued.

12. The learning that is just in books
and wealth that is in some others’ hands
are not knowledge or affluence
when for these there is a need.

17
1. Those who study just from books
and not beside a teacher
do not look good in assemblies,
like a girl impregnated by some lover.

2. What of demerits if there is greed,
of other sins if there is malice,
of penance if one has truth,
of pilgrimage if the mind is pure?
Good nature is the best of merits—
of ornaments it is reputation,
death is better than disrepute,
and knowledge better than wealth.

3. One very poor becomes a monk,
one impotent a celibate,
one sick praying to god commences,
and a hag does go to the husband.

4. A snake’s venom is in its fangs,
the fly carries it in its head,
in its tail the scorpion,
and one wicked in his very being.

5. Water, left after washing feet,
or after the evening worship,
is like the urine of a dog—
if drunk, then keep the lunar fast.

6. The hand is graced by charity,
not by wearing bracelets;
a bath gives bodily purity,
not applying sandal paste;
respect, not food, contentment gives,
and it is wisdom, not decoration,
that leads people to salvation.

7. If the wife is beauteous, and
the son has merit and modesty,
and if he also has a son,
what greater happiness can there be?

8. Eating, sleeping, fear and sex
are the same in men and animals,
wisdom makes the man more special,
without it, he is just a beast.

9. Blinded are an elephant’s senses:
with flapping ears it swats away
the bees which seek its rutted temples
that makes them so splendid.
As for the bees, they onwards fly,
to lotus blooms, and there they lie.

10. Kings, courtesans, the god of death,
fire, children, thieves and beggars,
do not feel the pain of others:
the eighth are thorns in village lanes.

11. ‘What do you look for, below,
lady, what has fallen down?’
‘O Fool, you know not what is gone,
it is my pearl of youth.’

12. Fruitless, thorny, home to snakes,
twisted, mud-born, hard to get:
but your scent, O Ketaki plant,
makes you sought by creatures all—
a single merit can remove
all the faults that there may be.

1. Here described are signs of merit
in people who serve a sovereign,
and can his kingdom enhance,
as also the treasury. (CvA 4.7)
2. Such should be the ruler’s chaplain:
one who knows the essence of
the Vedas and related works
is given to prayer, meditation,
and bestowing holy blessings. (CvA 4.8)
3. Clever, skilled in observation,
and in judging the minds of others,
in speech precise, and also wise,
such should the king’s ambassador be. (CvA 4.9)
4. Attentive to techniques ancestral,
adept in recipes, cooking sweets,
attached to truth and purity:
thus is the regal chef described. (CvA 4.10)
5. Practiced in the Ayurveda,
looking gently at all people,
expert in understanding causes:
such is the royal physician. (CvA 4.11)
6. The scribe and copyist needs to be
intelligent and skilled in words,
learned, truthful, self-controlled,
one who looks at all texts equally. (CvA 4.12)
7. He knows the whole of equine science,
has skills to control harnessed horses,
and a heroic warrior quality:
such is the chief of the cavalry. (CvA 4.13)
8. Dismiss a chief too given to anger,
with no discrimination, special skills,
and one with insufficient judgement:
he leads only to destruction. (CvA 4.14)
9. Officers idle, obstinate,
and to habits bad addicted,
not devoted, dissatisfied—
the king should such people discard. (CvA 4.15)
10. Teaching or advising fools
may excite them, but brings no peace:
as giving serpents milk to drink
only their venom enhances. (CvA 4.17)
11. A horse asleep, a rutting elephant,
a cow in its first delivery,
a king gone into the inner apartment;
avoid all these at every cost. (CvA 7.9)
12. The night sky’s lamp is the shining moon,
after dawn it is the sun,
a good son is the family’s lamp,
and dharma of all three worlds. (CvA 7.12)
13. What can adversaries do
to a person with wisdom equipped?
Just as a stream of rain, or heat
to one with a parasol protected? (CvA 8.14)
1. Listening to it, one does not get
peace or virtue, and is even repulsed.
Whatever should this be studied for;
it’s like the cawing of a crow.

2. Scholarship in bits and pieces,
sex purchased or put on sale,
and food on someone else dependent:
all three are mockery of people.

3. Parrots and other birds that speak
are caged for their vocal sins;
but the quiet stork is not:
silence gives the best results.

5. One whose character is not known—
nor his learning or family—
which clear-sighted man would trust
such a personality?

7. Grabbing the money of other people,
or a slim girl’s budding breasts,
a fool’s tormenting of another,
these spoil all that can be good.

8. Common folk are ruined by
lions in the shape of kings,
tigers who are their ministers,
and vultures their orderlies.

9. Warriors and learned folk,
and ladies who are beautiful—
wherever such people go,
they are deemed respected.

10. Merits become emissaries
of the good in distant places:
to the screw pine bees by themselves come
on scenting its fragrant flowers.

11. Merits are hailed everywhere,
the line of birth is meaningless:
people salute the son Vaasudeva,
not Vasudeva, the father.

12. One does hear a lot about
those great in age and holiness,
but they all like servants stand
at the door of one with great wealth.

13. The line of letters inscribed on
a person’s brow by Chitragupta,
recorder of the underworld,
cannot ever be erased
even by the scribes divine.

14. Sword-bearers and pen-pushers,
the decorators of a temple’s idols,
those who do its sacrificing,
and its cooks and launderers:
these six types of priests become
members of the menial class. (LC–A)
15. Sins which have their roots in greed,
sicknesses in pleasure rooted,
and pains rooted in affections:
give up all three and happy be. (LC–K).
1. Scholarship and royal rule
are never comparable—
the king is honoured in his land,
the learned scholar everywhere.

2. Do not say impossible things,
even when seen by your own eyes,
like a rock in water floating,
or the monkey singing a song.

3. Wise folk think of wealth and learning
as if they will forever live,
but so act, in accord with dharma,
as if death already grasps their hair.

4. By the kinsmen never plundered,
nor carried off by thieves,
by donation never depleted:
learning’s gems are the greatest wealth.

5. Snakes are pitiless, so are villains,
but villains are always more so:
spells and drugs can ward off serpents,
but whatever can control the villain?

6. The learned folk, the warriors,
and those who are in service:
these three respectively prefer
flowers, gold and land.

7. On who tries again to bring
his enemy and his friend together,
that person with death is sporting,
like a pregnant she-mule.

8. The wise, while walking, take but one step,
and stop before another:
without checking the next position,
they do not leave the previous one.

9. When at home there is no mother,
nor a wife who sweetly speaks,
one should then to a forest go,
for home is but a wilderness.

10. Life is void without some learning,
the quarters void with no family,
with no son, the home is void,
and all is void in poverty.

11. A life devoid of learning is
like a dress without any ornament,
or a meal that has no ghee,
and a woman with no bosom.

12. Where is virtue in a thief,
where forgiveness in the wicked,
where is love in a courtesan,
and truth in those who lust for one?

13. A weak person’s strength is in the king,
for a child it is in tears,
a fool’s strength lies in silence,
of a thief it is in falsehood.

14. Meat gone dry, and women aged,
the sun still rising, just-set yoghurt,
sex at dawn, and sleep thereafter;
for life, these six are dangerous.

15. There is no friend like knowledge,
nor like disease an enemy,
no strength greater than good luck,
and no love as in calamity.

16. Land is by the sea protected,
the fence protects the house,
the king protects the country, and
their conduct the womenfolk.

17. Woman is like a pot of ghee
and man a burning brazier—
both ghee and fire in one place
wise people do not keep together.

18. Trees are fearful of the wind,
lotus blooms of the winter,
mountains fear the thunderbolt,
and good folk the wicked.

19. The water in wells, the banyan tree’s shade,
a lovely dark girl, one’s favourite house:
all these are in the winter warm,
and in hot weather cool.

20. At the first stage was no learning got,
in the second stage no wealth,
in the third, no blessed work performed,
in the fourth, what will one do?

1. Who will not rise up so high
in being with the best?
Twigs, strung into floral wreaths,
get placed upon one’s crest.

2. Mount Meru’s peak is not too high,
nor hell’s pits so deep below,
the ocean is no barrier,
for those persistent and resolved.

3. Wandering, an ant does travel
a thousand miles or more,
but, motionless, even an eagle
cannot go a single step.

4. The person wishing for union
with one who is an enemy
is sleeping on the tip of a branch,
on waking up falls down the tree.

5. When the crop is always good,
and the husband loves the spouse,
free of illness, always happy,
always festive is that house.

6. The purity of people’s feelings
may be seen in all their actions:
with one feeling is the mistress kissed,
with another is the daughter.

7. Industry, steadiness and daring,
valour, strength and intellect,
one with whom these six are there,
he even the gods does scare.

8. Good talker, helpful, pleased with merit,
enjoying his time with followers,
adept in law, in war a fighter,
these are five signs of the king.

9. A sharp foe may be neutralized
with the help of another enemy:
a thorn that gets stuck in the foot
with another thorn can extracted be.

10. O tongue, you always love the bitter,
why do you not speak sweetly?
Say sweet words, O blessed one,
the world loves all things sweet.

11. You are a hundred, we but five,
but in our mutual opposition,
and bravery against the other,
more than a hundred we five are.

12. After pain can pleasure come,
and after pleasure, pain,
it is like a wheel rotating,
mankind’s conditions change again.

13. A lemon tree that has been planted
in a field of sugar cane,
and watered with milk and honey,
can its fruits some sweetness gain?

14. If one seeks eternal happiness,
three things should not be done:
gambling and supplication,
and gazing at another’s wife.

15. With sons and grandchildren surrounded,
and a crowd of maids and servants,
for the man who has now lost his wife,
the home is but a wilderness.

16. Bad women destroy the family,
bad sons the clan entire,
advisers bad destroy the king,
its thieves destroy the state.

17. Where doing is the main consideration,
what is the need for thinking?
Where is it in a bit of rock
that will be carved into a god?

18. The motion of both women and rivers
is like a water current;
a river sinks embankments, and
a woman can sink the family.

19. A tree that stands behind a vine,
a king behind the servants,
a man standing behind young women:
all need to be suspected.

20. All these deserve to be respected:
the wife who is now past her youth,
a warrior coming back from battle,
and a corn crop coming home.

21. What is not done should not be done
even if life is at its end,
what should be done, do that alone,
even if life is at its end.

22. Laws are understood with knowledge,
with ignorance they cannot be,
though a lamp is lit for him,
a blind one simply cannot it see.

23. Flies and insects look for sores,
rulers look to fleece,
quarrels are by base folk sought,
good people look for peace.

24. Face shapely as a lotus bloom,
words cooling like the paste of sandal,
but a dagger in the heart:
these are three signs of a rascal.

25. To raise the arm and scratch an itch,
to quarrel or to gamble,
to have wine or another’s woman,
to be lazy due to sleep or ease:
these practices do always make
each one of them increase.

26. When the king is himself a thief,
his priests and his ministers too,
then whatever will I do,
for I will ever be afraid
of their protection too.

27. There is no sin in eating meat,
in drinking liquor or having sex,
but better than them is being content
with mankind’s advancement.

1. Satisfied with but a little,
always keeping happy, and
not given to wrong expenditure:
a person having such a spouse
is not human, but a king of gods.

2. That life is fruitful and fulfilling,
in the course of which they also live—
one’s cherished friends and family:
for oneself, who does not live?

3. Though they are born in a single setting,
different are their looks and smells:
of lotus blossoms and their leaves,
of the fish and of the lilies.

4. The wife is one half of the body,
from her comes the best of joys,
of worldly ends she is the root,
and her friendship never ends.

6. In duties an adviser, in doing chores a servant-maid,
like the earth forgiving, like a mother in love,
in law the wife, in bed a mistress:
these six roles, performed by women,
raise high and save the family.

7. With flowing rut is the elephant splendid,
with lotus blooms the water,
night with the full moon, speech with grammar,
with swans rivers, with scholars councils,
with constant festivals the temples,
land with fruit, with good sons family,
and, with the god Shambhu, all three worlds.

8. Better a scholar, poor but learned,
not one rich with no character,
bright eyes grace a person feeble,
not gold and jewels one who is blind.

9. When times are troubled, know the friend,
in war the brave, the pure in privacy,
the wife when wealth becomes depleted,
and a dear guest during a famine.

10. Birds abandon fruitless trees,
storks a lake that has gone dry,
girls discard a moneyless man,
and ministers kings corrupt,
bees avoid the flowers stale,
and deer forests then on fire:
all things please, in course of time,
but what is really loved by another?

12. Accept oblations, even from gods,
well-spoken words, even from children,
take gold out even from shit,
and the gem of a girl from a family low.

13. Gentleness decorates the scholar,
controlled speech the warrior,
patience does this for the wise,
and for the rich, humility,
for ascetics it is self-control,
forgiveness for the powerful,
and for law, being impartial:
all these are due to feelings pure,
the greatest jewel is character.

14. Eloquent, and a talker wise,
able to handle opposition,
steadfast, speaking as instructed,
such should an ambassador be.

15. On someone is their sleep dependent,
their work upon another’s thoughts,
their laughter has no happiness,
and wept tears no grief,
their bodies are used for hire,
and carry marks of teeth:
these are the very frightful pains
in this world for courtesans.

16. The betel leaf is bitter and sweet,
caustic and coloured with red;
wind, phlegm and germs it keeps away
and destroys bad smells;
it purifies, decorates the mouth,
and lights desire’s flames:
friend, these are its thirteen merits,
hard to find even in heaven.

17. Women play with worthless people,
clouds rain upon the hills,
wealth to wicked folk accrues,
the learned too often are poor.

18. Blessed are they who do not see
their country break, their family fall,
their wife with someone else at heart,
and their son in some addiction.

19. Magnificence, and the mango’s shade,
the scoundrel’s love, the harlot’s passion,
the graciousness of a royal ruler:
know these five do pass away.

20. A thorn that is stuck in the body,
a tooth that has begun to shake,
and a state’s minister wicked:
their pulling out from the root gives joy.

21. Not for the loved one any favour,
or a disfavour to enemies,
the birth of a baby only is
for the mother’s womb relief.

22. If your going is indeed definite,
why go in such a hurry?
For a few moments just stay here,
so I may have some happiness.
The world is like a leaking bucket,
from which life keeps dripping out:
who knows if we will meet again?

23. Merits are merits, certainly
,
with those who do them understand;
getting to the meritless,
they do also faults become:
water, in the river delicious,
in the sea turns undrinkable.
